text: hello this is chef john from food wishes
comm with sushi rice that's right just
because you don't make sushi at home
does not mean you should learn how to
make sushi rice since this stuff is a
very versatile and underrated side dish
in fact I almost never make this to use
for actual sushi but much more so to
serve alongside things like grilled
meats or as you saw recently with some
completely authentic Hawaiian poke a but
anyway I did mention I'd show you how to
make it and that's what we're gonna do
and it's going to start by finding some
of this sushi rice which is you can
probably see as a short grain variety
and this stuff's actually sold in
different grades and what that's based
on is how perfect the grains of rice are
alright with your higher grades
everything is going to be uniformly
sized with virtually no broken grains as
opposed to the lower less expensive
grades which by the way is what I'm
using which won't be quite as perfect in
fact if you look closely here you can
see lots of broken grains and just
general irregularity but the good news
is even this lower quality sushi rice
still comes out very nice especially
considering we're not usually going to
use this to make sushi with so what
we'll do is we'll dump a couple cups of
our sushi rice in a strainer and we will
head over to the sink where we're going
to run this under cold water for a
couple minutes to rinse off the starch
and what we're looking for is for that
runoff to go from cloudy and starchy to
clear and starch free so don't be in a
hurry give it a couple minutes until
like I said that runoff water is
completely clear and then once that's
happened what we'll do is set that
strainer in a bowl and let it dry for
one hour
and by the way some people do consider
this an unnecessary step but I'm not one
of those people I'm definitely into the
hour drying method so I'm gonna let my
rice sit there for exactly one hour
absorbing that water and dry it out at
which point I'm going to transfer that
into a heavy-bottomed saucepan something
that has a nice tight-fitting lid and
we'll go ahead and add our water and if
you haven't done this before it's
probably less than you would imagine but
anyway we're going to add our water and
head to the stove to start the cooking
process and all that entails is placing
this over medium high heat and bringing
it up to a simmer and by the way don't
stir this just stand there and stare at
it and as soon as we can see little
bubbles starting to form around the edge
we know we're getting close so don't go
anywhere because what's going to happen
as soon as this just starts to simmer
what we'll do is quickly cover it
turn our heat down to low and set our
timer for exactly ten minutes and by the
way during this 10 minute period don't
go anywhere because as soon as that
timer rings we have to do two things
very quickly okay as soon as that rice
has cooked exactly ten minutes on low
we're going to turn off the heat we're
going to lift the lid up for exactly one
second we're going to quickly place the
lid back down and we're going to set our
timer for another ten minutes at which
point we'll be able to move to the final
step which is blending in the rice
vinegar all right so while we're waiting
for our timer to ring we'll go ahead and
get our stuff together for that process
and I'm actually going to show you this
two different ways today I'm going to
show you the way I usually do it which I
prefer and then the slightly more
traditional method so what I'm going to
need handy once that timer rings is a
sheet pan to toss this on some seasoned
rice vinegar a fork with which to work
it in as well as a magazine to fan it oh
he has we're going to fan our rice so
what we'll do as soon as our timer rings
is transfer that rice onto our sheet pan
and then basically what's going to
happen here is we're going to sprinkle
in our rice vinegar while we sort of
separate and fluff that rice with our
fork and while we're doing that we'll
give it the occasional fan with our
magazine and I generally like to do this
in two editions so I'll sprinkle over
about half that seasoned vinegar just
sort of dripping it in with my
fingertips here and there mixing it in
as we fluff and fan that rice it really
is helpful if you can do two different
things with your arms at the same time I
don't really have that skill but even so
it still worked then once I was mixed in
I went ahead and added the rest and all
we need to do here is continue mixing
that with the fork while we fan this
until the temperature of the rice is
just barely over room temperature and by
the way the reason we want to fan this
is so it cools down a little quicker
which apparently improves the texture
and helps create that gorgeous
pearlescent look okay so that's the
thing they're supposed to give the sushi
rice that little bit of glossiness so
like I said we'll continue doing that
until our rice cools to just barely over
room temperature which was the point I
was at right here and yes I could see a
couple drips of rice vinegar don't worry
I'll mix those in but what I want to do
right now is stop so I can show you how
you know this came out right so let me
grab some of this rice and by the way to
work with this stuff you always have to
have damp hands otherwise it's going to
stick
and I'm going to form this into that
kind of log shape usually see under the
raw fish and what will happen if your
sushi rice was properly made you'll be
able to mold it into any shape you want
and it will hold together and be sturdy
enough to lay a piece of fish over the
top but when we bite into this which
I'll demonstrate with a fork it will
pretty much crumble and collapse back
into those individual grains of rice so
that right there is what you're shooting
for we want all the grains to be
separate and perfectly cooked but still
sticky enough to shape into whatever
we're going to use it for so what you
just saw was my preferred method with
the pan and the fork but what's more
typical is for people to do this in a
bowl using a thin bamboo rice paddle
which by the way I don't have but I do
have a wooden spoon that's about the
same thickness except it has a hole in
the middle but it's pretty much going to
work the same and whether you're going
to do with a fork or the more
traditional bamboo rice paddle it's
still the same process the one major
difference for me and I'm not sure if
this is correct
because I'm using the bowl I'll just
sprinkle in all the rice vinegar at once
so with the pan method it makes more
sense for me to add it in two additions
but since we're using a bowl here it
feels like it's okay to add the vinegar
at once in one difference I find using
this method the rice does come out a
little stickier and I think that's just
from the fact that using this paddle
we're rubbing more starch off the grains
as we're mixing this up so anyway I
continued on and I finish this batch
with the wooden paddle using the exact
same technique and once I was set I wet
my hands again so I could grab some of
this so we could compare and I tried to
form it into the exact same shape and
size and to be honest it pretty much
came out exactly the same except like I
said slightly stickier now is that from
30 seconds more cooking time or was my
water measurement a tablespoon off who
knows but for my experience using both
methods using the fork and sheet pan
instead of the Bowlin paddle the rice
does come out a little less sticky so I
guess it's just up to your personal
preference you are the Vincent Price of
your sushi rice so don't be scared pick
a method and be confident and it will
work and then as far as service goes if
we are making sushi we'll probably want
to cover this with a damp towel so it
doesn't dry out as we're working but as
I mentioned in the intro I rarely make
this to do sushi with mostly because I
don't know how to make sushi oh sure I
can shape this into a log and maybe top
it with a thin slice of marinated tuna
actually maybe I do know how to make
sushi but not very well so when I make
this it's usually to serve as a side and
not only does this taste better than
regular rice because we've kicked it up
with that seasoned rice vinegar but
above and beyond this deliciousness it
has such a user-friendly texture I mean
again all the grains are separate and
perfectly cooked yet it is very easy to
press together into clumps which makes
it very chopstick friendly so this stuff
really is fantastic as a side dish
bought one last bonus suggestion one
thing I love to do is take one of those
sheets of nori seaweed and cut it in
quarters and then using wet fingers of
course will press down a little bit of
that sushi rice not too much just a thin
layer and don't smash it down too much
use a nice light touch and what I like
to do after applying a little bit of
that sushi rice to the seaweed is tap it
with some kind of flavorful meat which
this time was a little experiment I did
with some spicy sesame beef no that's
not video worthy yet as well as some
fresh cilantro and some hot sauce and
then what I'll do is kind of bring up
these corners like this and make what I
guess we'll call a seaweed and sushi
rice taco check it out these really are
an incredibly fun and delicious
variation on the taco plus since we're
not using tortilla this is totally
low-carb except for the rice and I went
with skirt steak here but this same
technology will work with so many
different things like I said even if you
don't make sushi at home which most
normal people don't you still really
should have this incredible rice recipe
in your arsenal as I hopefully just
demonstrated it's just not for sushi
anymore so I really do hope you give
that a try soon head over to food
whooshes calm for all the ingredient
amounts and more info as usual and as
always enjoy
you
